name.text: Working out the surface area of a pyramid from its net

questiontext.text:
The figure below shows a pyramid. Sketch the net of the pyramid and work out the surface area of the pyramid from its net

Note:Round off your final answer to 2 decimal places.

[[jsxgraph]] var board = JXG.JSXGraph.initBoard('jxgbox', { boundingbox: [-50, 500, 500, -50], keepAspectRatio: true, axis: false, showCopyright: false }); // ----------- POINTS (rectangular base + apex) ----------- // Rectangle base (longer in x-direction) var A = board.create('point', [100, 150], {name: 'A', size: 2, color: 'black'}); var B = board.create('point', [350, 150], {name: 'B', size: 2, color: 'black'}); var C = board.create('point', [300, 300], {name: 'C', size: 2, color: 'black'}); var D = board.create('point', [80, 300], {name: 'D', size: 2, color: 'black'}); // Apex (centered above the base) var V = board.create('point', [200, 430], {name: 'V', size: 2, color: 'black'}); // ----------- BASE RECTANGLE (orange) ----------- var base = board.create('polygon', [A, B, C, D], { borders: {strokeColor: 'black'}, fillColor: 'orange', fillOpacity: 0.8, vertices: {visible: false} }); // ----------- SIDE FACES (cyan tones) ----------- var face1 = board.create('polygon', [V, A, B], { borders: {strokeColor: 'black'}, fillColor: 'cyan', fillOpacity: 0.6, vertices: {visible: false} }); var face2 = board.create('polygon', [V, B, C], { borders: {strokeColor: 'black'}, fillColor: 'cyan', fillOpacity: 0.7, vertices: {visible: false} }); var face3 = board.create('polygon', [V, C, D], { borders: {strokeColor: 'black'}, fillColor: 'cyan', fillOpacity: 0.5, vertices: {visible: false} }); var face4 = board.create('polygon', [V, D, A], { borders: {strokeColor: 'black'}, fillColor: 'cyan', fillOpacity: 0.65, vertices: {visible: false} }); // ----------- EDGES TO APEX ----------- board.create('segment', [A, V], {strokeColor: 'black'}); board.create('segment', [B, V], {strokeColor: 'black'}); board.create('segment', [C, V], {strokeColor: 'black'}); board.create('segment', [D, V], {strokeColor: 'black'}); // ----------- LABELS ----------- board.create('text', [190, 130, ' {#length#} cm'], {fontSize: 14, color: 'black'}); board.create('text', [340, 240, ' {#width#} cm'], {fontSize: 14, color: 'black'}); board.create('text', [270, 360, '{#slanting_height#} cm'], {fontSize: 14, color: 'black'}); [[/jsxgraph]]

(b).\(\begin{align}\text{Base area}&=Length \times Width\\&={@length@} cm\times {@width@} cm\\&={@base_area@} cm^2\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Vertical height of triangle A and B}&=\sqrt{{@slanting_height@}^2-{@half_length@}^2}\\&=\sqrt {{@slanting_height^2@}-{@half_length^2@}}\\&{@vertical_height1@} cm\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Area of triangle A}&=\frac{1}{2} \times base \times height\\&=\frac{1}{2} \times {@length@} cm\times {@vertical_height1@} cm\\&={@area_of_triangle_A@} cm^2\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Area of triangle B}&=\frac{1}{2} \times base \times height\\&=\frac{1}{2} \times {@length@} cm\times {@vertical_height1@} cm\\&={@area_of_triangle_B@} cm^2\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Vertical height of triangle C and D}&=\sqrt{{@slanting_height@}^2-{@half_width@}^2}\\&=\sqrt {{@slanting_height^2@}-{@half_width^2@}}\\&{@vertical_height2@} cm\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Area of triangle C}&=\frac{1}{2} \times base \times height\\&=\frac{1}{2} \times {@width@} cm\times {@vertical_height2@} cm\\&={@area_of_triangle_C@} cm^2\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Area of triangle D}&=\frac{1}{2} \times base \times height\\&=\frac{1}{2} \times {@width@} cm \times {@vertical_height2@} cm\\&={@area_of_triangle_D@} cm^2\end{align}\)

\(\begin{align}\text{Total surface area}&={@base_area@} cm^2+{@area_of_triangle_A@} cm^2+{@area_of_triangle_B@} cm^2+{@area_of_triangle_C@} cm^2+{@area_of_triangle_D@} cm^2\\ &={@ta@} cm^2\end{align}\)

truefeedback.text: It looks like you confused the slanting height of the triangle with the vertical height when calculating the area. Keep in mind that the height used in the calculation of the area of a triangle must be perpendicular to the base. You're on the right track, just be careful to identify the correct height next time
